qas.question: When does NCO status occur in the USAF?

answers.text: when an enlisted person reaches the pay grade of E-5

qas.question: When does NCO status happen in all other branches of the US Military?
What must a Senior Airman do to become a supervisor in the USAF?
What rank is NCO status achieved in the US Army?

context: The USAF is the only branch of the U.S. military where NCO status is achieved <a0_0>when an enlisted person reaches the pay grade of E-5<a0_0/>. In all other branches, NCO status is generally achieved at the <a1_0>pay grade of E-4<a1_0/> (e.g., a <a3_0>Corporal<a3_0/> in the Army and Marine Corps, Petty Officer Third Class in the Navy and Coast Guard). The Air Force mirrored the Army from 1976 to 1991 with an E-4 being either a Senior Airman wearing three stripes without a star or a Sergeant (referred to as "Buck Sergeant"), which was noted by the presence of the central star and considered an NCO. Despite not being an NCO, a Senior Airman who has <a2_0>completed Airman Leadership School<a2_0/> can be a supervisor according to the AFI 36-2618.
